summary: Slow-witted Forrest Gump (Tom Hanks) has never thought of himself as disadvantaged, and thanks to his supportive mother (Sally Field), he leads anything but a restricted life. Whether dominating on the gridiron as a college football star, fighting in Vietnam or captaining a shrimp boat, Forrest inspires people with his childlike optimism. But one person Forrest cares about most may be the most difficult to save -- his childhood love, the sweet but troubled Jenny (Robin Wright).

There's a scene in Forrest Gump that encapsulates the film. Jenny, who is dying from an STD, asks Forrest if he was scared in Vietnam. Forrest then tells Jenny about the stars in Vietnam, the sunset he saw from the shrimp boat, and the mountain lake from his cross-country run. Forrest even mentions a desert sunrise so stunning that he didn't know "where heaven stopped and the earth began." 

Forrest sees the beauty in everything. He took a question about fear and spun it into poetic gold. This is why we love him. His attitude and childlike wonder towards life represents humanity at its best. Something to aspire to. Based on the novel by Winston Groom, and adapted by the amazing Eric Roth, Forrest Gump is an opus about the power of optimism and how to endure life's pain. Forrest Gump masterfully depicts the hero's journey with amazing plotting and structure. It's a journey I want to take time and time again. 

Robert Zemeckis is a pro storyteller and crafts each scene with the right amount of humor, nostalgia, intensity, and human emotion. The framing device of Forrest telling his story is perfect. We get to live inside Gump's head and see a heightened version of reality from his mind's eye. It's a dream, fairy tale, magic trick, and memory all in one. 

Forrest Gump grew up in Greenbow, Alabama during the 1950s. Zemeckis paints Greenbow with Norman Rockwell idealism. Childhood is a time of wonder but Zemeckis doesn't let us live there Scott free. Forrest has to deal with a single mother, a low IQ, leg braces, and bullies. Zemeckis is genuine about the story he's telling. Only a director that earnest can pull off a joke about Mrs. Gump banging the school principle and make it work. 

All of these characters come from a place of Southern Boomer love and affection. The genius of Forrest Gump is the contrast between Forrest's naive innocence and Jenny's cynical life crisis. We get two opposite journeys in one. Forrest is the vanilla protagonist and audience stand in. He's an ordinary man who experiences the extraordinary. Forrest Gump is wish fulfillment. He's a country boy that sees the world. He's the feather that floats in the wind. 

Forrest isn't focused on the destination, he's just in love with the journey. His heart may pine for Jenny and Greenbow but Forrest makes the best of where he is. He embraces the now. James Cameron once said that a movie doesn't have to be possible it just has to be probable. The byproduct of Forrest's low IQ and social awkwardness is that he has extreme focus. He can assemble a gun and play ping pong better than anyone. He can run from coast to coast and keep a pace. 

Forrest pops up in so many historical moments that we half expect him to reveal the Watergate scandal that led to Nixon's resignation. This explanation is enough for the audience. In the army, Forrest finds a second family. Bubba becomes a brother to Forrest. "I gotta find Bubba" is the ultimate heartbreaking plea. Lieutenant Dan becomes the mentor and father figure that Forrest needs. Dan is a no nonsense bad ass who challenges Forrest and grows to respect him. 

There's a scene where Forrest is recuperating at a VA hospital by enjoying ice cream. This moment is interrupted when Forrest receives a stack of "Return to Sender" letters that he sent to Jenny. This is classic Zemeckis. He gives you bliss one moment and breaks your heart into a thousand pieces the next. With Zemeckis we never know what we're gonna get.

Lieutenant Dan goes through the crazy character development that Forrest doesn't. After getting both his legs amputated, Dan becomes a shell of himself. He's a cigar-chomping drunk with a crisis of faith. He hates that Forrest saved his life. Dan has a lot of reinventing to do. When Forrest buys a shrimp boat, Dan agrees to be his first mate. 

There's an amazing scene where Forrest and Dan survive a hurricane. When the storm clears, the duo have more shrimp then they know what to do with. Peacefully floating in the water, Dan thanks Forrest for saving his life and then makes his peace with God. Dan gets new legs and a new lease on life.

Jenny spends the whole movie running from her demons. She tries to fill the void left by her abusive childhood and only half succeeds. She returns home to Greenbow but she's not ready to stay. She's not done running. Forrest is crushed and the only way he can deal with his pain is to run. He runs for three years and eventually his heart begins to heal. 

When Forrest sits at the bus stop at the beginning and end he's wearing the old pair of Nikes that Jenny got him. To Forrest, the little things in life are the big things. At the end of Back to Future, Marty is rewarded with a better life. Some people don't like this ending but this is classic Zemeckis optimism. Forrest goes through hell and he gets rewarded for it. This is the hope of the film. We want to believe that every disadvantage contains an equal or more powerful advantage. We want to believe in the spiritual concept that all things work together for the good. 

When Forrest reunites with Jenny it's the healthiest we've seen her the whole movie. She has finally found peace. At the end, Forrest walks his son to the bus stop and the movie comes full circle. Zemeckis doesn't just wrap a present, he puts a bow on top. 1994 was a great year for film and against distinguished competition Forrest Gump won six Academy Awards including Best Director, Best Screenplay, and a second Oscar for Tom Hanks. 

Is Forrest Gump really that good? I believe it is. Alan Silvestri composed an amazing score and the film features a remarkable song list from the 1960s and 1970s. Forrest Gump may not be for everyone but it hit me right where I live. Robert Zemeckis and Eric Roth's ode through 20th century America is as sweet as a box of chocolates. And that's all I have to say about that.

Undoubtedly, one of the greatest films of all time, Forrest Gump, does everything well. The cinematography and visual effects are great; there was nothing that made me question the director's choices. It's a touching story about Gump's journey through life as a disabled man who is also incredibly dutiful, hardworking, and, in some ways, wise. He never complains, and he just does, and I honestly like that way of life, which is simple and fulfilling. The story is mostly that of a slice of life because it's quite literally just Gump's life, but there is also a lot of drama, action, and history throughout the movie, which is why I think anyone can watch this movie and enjoy it. The characters were written beautifully. Many people seem to despise Gump and Jenny's relationship, but I believe it is one of the most profound love stories ever written. Juxtaposed, the two characters are very different people who go down very different routes in life. In the end, they finally get together, even though they have clearly loved each other for a long time. To analyze the relationship between the two would take a whole essay, but trust me, it's a tear-jerker. The performances by all the important characters were also great, but especially Tom Hanks, who plays Gump really well; he really came off as authentically disabled.

What more is their to say about this Tom Hanks performance, just incredible. Robin Wright and Gary Sinise are incredible in this movie, as wall as Sally Field of course. The VFX are incredible, as well as production design and every other technical detail, such as editing. Man i miss a score like this one, so iconic and with so much emotion. The friendship and love that Gump builds in this movie all leads to such a beautiful emotional payoff, which made me cry so much. This is a story, that even if you are not the smartest, most beautiful or richest person in the world, succes finds you when it wants to find you.

Forrest Gump is my favorite movie of all time. Over the course of the film, you watch Forrest Gump's life. You watch young Forrest go from leg braces, to by the end of the film, running around the country for three years straight (literally), as well as pretty much everything in between. Seriously, the man plays for two different sports, serves in the military, becomes a shrimp boat captain, invests in a company that makes him a BILLIONAIRE, and a whole lot more. The thing that has always stood out to me about Forrest is his unshakable view of the world. As narrow and misunderstanding he may be, he sure does have a beautiful look on life, and it all pays out in the end. I have very seldom ever found myself tearing up during a film, but this film sure nails the emotions it wants to project to its audience. Forrest Gump will make you happy, sad, scared, disgusted, angered, laugh, and everything in between. This film is a very well-rounded story and the performances from the whole cast are extremely believable and makes you ever more invested in the events that the movie welcomes you into. I would be remissed if I did not give praise to the film's incredible editing. The film spends a lot of time showing famous events in the world's history and does a fantastic job of editing Forrest into the real clips in an awe-inspiring way, which just further invests me as a huge fan of world and American history. From exciting cameos such as Elvis Presley, John Lennon, and JFK, to amazing recreations of events like the guerilla warfare in Vietnam, this movie was not very short of perfection in integrating history into the movie's plot. Last but not least, this movie told a very intriguing love story. Jenny and Forrest are lifelong friends. During the whole movie, Forrest romantically pursues a relationship with Jenny, while Jenny is confused and is very on-and-off with her feelings towards Forrest. When he tells her that he loves her, she replies "Forrest... You don't know what love is". That moment perfectly describes they're entire relationship. Although he may be misunderstanding about things, and may be confused at points in his life, he's always known that he has loved Jenny. Jenny has been traumatized her whole life and is not ready to love until the very end. I am serious when I say that the last five to six minutes of the film are really a tearjerker with some of the most beautiful lines of dialogue I've ever heard in a film. Overall, this film is a masterpiece to me and it doesn't get much better than this. I totally recommend if you have not seen it already.

I've always liked Tom Hanks' acting, and this film was no different; I was happy to watch it, and by this point, I'd seen it three or four times since the performance and story line are so powerful.

This film follows a group of talented actors who help to the film's production. To begin with, Tom Hanks gives a very good and unforgettable performance in this film. Tom Hanks' role, Forrest Gump, is a plain and slow-witted country kid. We learn about his life, his everyday sayings that help him get by, and how he casually participates in some of the most major events of the 1960s. it's Simple, yet nice. It's a touch too direct and emotional for my tastes, but it's powerful. It's not profound, but it's rather pleasant if you don't think too hard about it. It's amazing to watch how true historical events are mixed into the storyline and film, and it also adds a brilliant humorous element to the film. It's a beautiful film. due to historical truths and a pleasurable experience It's a beautifully created work of art. for the film's cast members' one-of-a-kind performances It's a fantastic story in which the good guys win. Be open to the ideals of the time period as well as the unique and pleasant sense of humor.

If I had to add anything, I would advise people who are easily triggered by historical events to avoid certain parts of the film because historical events are depicted in the film, primarily flashbacks to the beginning that do not come across as kind when it talks about the Ku Klux Klan (Ku Klux Klan), and I would also suggest hiding some scenes from children because there are scenes that suggest a sex event is about to occur. and includes scenes of bulling and battles that may not be suitable for all viewers. However, you must be of mature to comprehend and accept some ideas till then. You'll also need a sense of humor to appreciate Gump's activities.

As a result, I would recommend that people watch this film because all of the cast members give outstanding performances. The story above, in my opinion, underlines the most important messages that we should all remember throughout our lives. Instead of focusing on your weaknesses, examine your opportunities. Make the most of what you've got. Always give your best effort, respect others, and be willing to learn from others. This will be a wonderful movie for you if you can dig all of the stuff I described earlier and go with the flow. You must be in the right mood and state of mind to enjoy it because this film will truly fully immerse you.

Forrest Gump, I think is a beautiful film. Never too schmaltzy, but there are some genuine tearjerkers like Forrest at Jenny's grave. The cinematography is stunning, the costumes are lovely and the scenery is gorgeous. The music is also very calm and relaxing, perhaps adding to the tone of this film. The screenplay is well crafted, and the story is simple. But what made this movie was its simplicity; it never tries to be too complex and is consequently moving. The acting is just as impressive; whilst Tom Hanks's accent is a little awkward in places, my only real criticism of this movie, he gives a truly remarkable performance, though I do think Morgan Freeman deserved the Oscar more for Shawshank. Robin Wright gives possibly the best performance of her career, and Sally Field is very dignified as Forrest's mother. The scene stealer though is Gary Sinise as Lieutenant Dan, a very moving and insightful performance. Overall, an extremely good movie, I will admit I wasn't sure whether I would like it, but the simple answer is this, I do. 9/10 Bethany Cox

It's not every day that a movie released will still maintain relevancy nearly three decades later, but Forrest Gump has proven itself to be a timeless movie and a blockbuster of its time. I have watched this movie numerous times and have somewhat of a habit of going back and watching this movie at least once every couple of years. I love the way that Forrest Gump's story is told by Forrest's naivete so that throughout the story we can infer what happened through the imagery and inferences. To those who are on the fence about watching this movie because it looks like it would be dull, I urge you to reconsider. This movie is extremely close to what I would consider being a masterpiece of its time due to the versatility of the scenes, the story that it wistfully guides you through as if you were spectating Forrest Gump's life in real-time, and my favorite part of this movie, the character development.
There is not much more that I enjoy in a movie as much as I enjoy seeing a character grow and change throughout a movie whether a character reaches a goal and is a different person because of it or even witnessing a character's descent into madness. This movie's character development had me enthralled with the storytelling skills and development of the characters Jenny, Forrest, and Lieutenant Dan. Jenny's character in this story plays an important role in Forrest's life as a love interest that he is constantly chasing through the bounds of the common trope of unrequited love. In the beginning, Jenny found Forrest as a genuine love interest, but throughout the years she grew distant from him perhaps looking for something more than what she had. We watch Jenny go on these adventures throughout the film as if she were searching for something that she had been missing or dreaming about but she never really seems happy with herself. She has then reunited with Forrest again near the end of the film and it is at that point that she finds out that what she truly missed out on was a comfortable life with Forrest. Tom Hanks performed the role of Forrest Gump exceptionally well to the point of becoming synonymous with him. Forrest does have some character development, but not in the traditional personality changing way that we often see in films and shows. Forrest changes others through his interactions, but he remains the same innocent and kind-hearted man as he was in the beginning. Lieutenant Dan however is a very strong case of character development done right. Upon meeting Lieutenant Dan, he appears to be a goal-orientated man with confidence, but after having a traumatic event happen to him, he feels degraded and cheated from his destiny by Forrest. However, we can witness Lieutenant Dan recuperate from his tragic downfall and come back stronger, and happier than he was before through events orchestrated, albeit accidentally, by Forrest again.
Again, this movie is the basis of what I would consider being a perfect example of movies done right with the correct execution of character development. For this reason, Forrest Gump has solidified itself in the rankings of my favorite movies I've watched to date.

Among other things, Robert Zemeckis' Forrest Gump asks the following question:  in life, are we guided by destiny or is life a random series of events?  If you can ignore the fact that the movie is shamelessly manipulative at times, it is a wildly entertaining ride through the life of the mentally disadvantaged Forrest Gump.  It covers the time period from the ‘50s to the ‘80s, with the titular hero inadvertently immersing himself in Vietnam, Watergate, Chinese diplomacy, and a variety of other scenarios.  The film is helped along by a great performance from Tom Hanks, a colorful story, some fantastic dialogue, wonderfully creative visual effects and a memorable soundtrack.  While it seems to be fashionable these days to slag the movie, it remains a powerful piece of filmmaking almost thirty years after it was released.

Combining elements of comedy, motivation to satire. Forrest Gump, a film directed by Robert Zemeckis and starring veteran actor Tom Hanks, manages to instill very deep moral values ​​in every scene. The film, which was made in 1994, deserves to be called the best film of all time. The film, based on the novel by Winston Groom, tells the story of a man named Forrest Gump. Forrest who since childhood was considered a stupid child with an IQ of 75 has a unique life story. Having been belittled by everyone, Forrest continued to go forward with a stupid label by others against him. Forrest Gump is an epic film that makes the audience realize that behind the shortcomings there are many advantages in each person. The nature of the main character Forrest Gump can certainly be a good example for everyone. So what kind of traits can we imitate from Forrest Gump's character?

1. Loving Parents
We can see how much Forrest Gump loves his mother. In the film he is willing to swim from the ocean and run through the city when he hears the news that his mother, Mrs. Gump is sick. Forrest Gump certainly realized that his mother's struggle could not be reciprocated with anything. The mother who always supports Forrest in the midst of his shortcomings makes Forrest realize that his mother is his hero
2. Always positive and optimistic
Although Forrest Gump is known as an idiot character in the film. But his stupidity is not a problem for a Forrest. He keeps going and always thinks positive. Don't complain and always try. In the film, Forrest Gump always shows his positive nature in any situation and in any crisis. Can you copy this?
3. Never give up and be generous
Of course, if you have watched the Forrest Gump movie, you will realize how generous the character Forrest Gump is. After he managed to create a shrimp company with the initials of his friend Bubba Gump Shrimp Corporation. He and Lieutenant Dan, a character frustrated by his disability during the Vietnam war, started a shrimp fishing business. After repeatedly failing to catch shrimp at the beginning of his search for shrimp. Forrest Gump didn't give up. He tried many times and of course failed many times. Until one day his shrimp catch was successful and together with Lieutenant Dan he managed to create the most successful shrimp fishing company in his city. Forrest Gump, who seemed to be a very successful businessman, didn't feel happy.Until finally he handed over his company to Lieutenant Dan and gave his income to the Bubba family, his best friend who had motivated him to start the shrimp fishing company
4. Good promise holder
Bubba is a black man whom Forrest met when he joined the military. Forrest and Bubba's relationship is quite unique. It's said that their friends don't seem too close. But this is the other side of the Forrest Gump movie. Bubba, who when he was with Forrest, always talked about the world of shrimp, of course, for many people who listened to him talk about shrimp, it was quite boring. But not with Forrest, he always listened to Bubba talk about shrimp and Bubba's dream that when he finished his military duty he would set up a shrimp company with Forrest. But unlucky, Bubba died on the battlefield. Until it was left Forrest with his promise with Bubba to set up a shrimp fishing company. Instead of burying the promise. Forrest kept his promise to his best friend Bubba by successfully founding a very successful company, the Bubba Gump Shrimp Corporation. Forrest's promise and dream with Bubba finally came true
5. Don't forget friends and best friends in any situation
The next Forrest Gump trait that you can emulate is that he always helps anyone. You can see it in the film even in critical times when Forrest and his troops are attacked by the enemy. Had separated well with his best friend Bubba and Lieutenant Dan. Forrest did not want to stay silent, he finally returned to the battlefield and saved his friends who were still alive even though they were full of wounds. No exception for Lieutenant Dan who he saved even though he had to lose his leg in the end. Lieutenant Dan, who was frustrated with his disability, was angry with Forrest. But again Forrest did not want to forget the Lieutenant Dan. He accidentally meets Lieutenant Dan who turns into a beggar in a wheelchair. Forrest, who at that time was a hero of his country, certainly felt sorry for Lieutenant Dan. Over time Forrest managed to raise new hope for Lieutenant Dan by getting him to join his shrimp fishing company. Lieutenant Dan joins in until Forrest gladly hands over the company he built to Lieutenant Dan. An extraordinary trait.
6. Faithful in love affairs
Not only comedy and motivational elements in the Forrest Gump film. Of course the romance drama between Forrest and Jenny can be a good example for everyone. The single love story between Forrest Gump and Jenny seems to break the audience's heart when they see how loyal Forrest Gump is to Jenny. Although he had been separated several times for a long time and many times Forrest Gump was rejected by Jenny and many times he saw Jenny's bad side. Forrest Gump remained standing faithfully waiting for Jenny. He still loves Jenny with all her flaws. Until finally he and Jenny got married. But the marriage did not last long because Jenny had to leave the world early due to a virus due to her wild life. Forrest Gump must have been very sad, Jenny's long-awaited love finally ended briefly. For Forrest Gump, Jenny was his first and last love.
7. Good father
At the end of the story, Forrest Gump who has become a father, gives his best love to his son. He applies the love he gets from his mother who is also a single parent. Without Jenny's presence, Forrest Gump performed his role appropriately to be a good father to his son. This film deserves to be watched and imitated in our daily lives because there are so many valuable messages and moral values ​​that we can follow in this film. This film, which has been nominated for 13 Academy Awards, you must watch this at least once in your life!!!!

The book this movie was based on, which I haven't read, was more satirical in tone, which explains the basic concept of a simpleton managing to have such great influence on American politics and culture without being aware of it. His childhood leg problem inspires Elvis Presley, he unintentionally mocks Lyndon Johnson's showing off his surgery scar, he goes to Maoist China to play Ping-Pong, he unintentionally starts the 1970's jogging fad, etc. The book's story was purposely contrived; the movie plays everything straight.

As for those who claim the movie glorifies stupidity, the phrase "Stupid is as stupid does" has a more honest message, namely that stupidity isn't an inability to think but an unwillingness to. As for the movie's uncomplimentary view of the counterculture, there was plenty of bad as well as good about the 1960's-divisiveness, racial and other hatred, violence, the spread of venereal diseases, etc. But not only the left gets skewered. Remember the scene where the legless Dan described being told he could "walk with Jesus"?

The acting serves to make the movie work, just as Monty Python's comedy worked by everyone being able to play it all straight.

Forrest Gump: A Simple Man in a Strange Land.

This week I watched the 1994 film Forrest Gump. Directed by Robert Zemeckis, the film stars Tom Hanks, Robin Wright, Gary Sinise and Sally Field and tells the story of a mentally disabled man named Forrest Gump who lives through and witnesses many crucial events of the 60's and 70's and with his innocent, hardworking yet simple nature seemingly lucks into a very successful life. Around Forrest are many people going through the turmoil of the times and while their lives are affected negatively by the tumultuous culture they cannot help being positively influenced by Forrest's simple and sweet nature. What struck me most about The film is what a straightforward and honest approach to filmmaking it is. The story manages to be heartwarming and uplifting without sugarcoating any aspects of what happened in the 60's and 70's and portraying what life was like for many who were young adults at the time. Each and every aspect of filmmaking is masterfully done and every trick in the book is used in it's impressive technical side but it's groundbreaking achievements and magnificently utilized tactics do not point us toward awe inspiring spectacle but instead draw us even nearer as an audience to the harsh realities and human lives that it portrays. I think the movie works so well because it is not attempting to be blatantly nostalgic and not trying to be saccharine about its subject matter but it uplifts the spirit and moves the soul in its soaring heights and devastating lows. It is the drama of life presented in a very real way with one central thing elevating it and lightening all the terrible things we see and hear throughout the course of the film: Forrest Gump. By centering on such a fascinating character that is completely unaffected by the chaotic world around him, who holds stubbornly to his old fashioned values and walks through life with simple goals that are not swayed by the tide of cultural upheaval around him, the film creates a new and powerful way to look at the events of the 60's and 70's but also a unique and meaningful way to look at life itself. The film is set in the 60's 70's but it is not tied down by a single time period. Forrest is a man apart from his time and thus apart from any time. The themes and characters are timeless in the questions they ask and the struggles they face and so a film set so conspicuously in such a crucial time in history is able to speak to what came before and what will come after it in an eloquence that only its title character could provide. Yet another masterclass in good filmmaking in all respects (and recipient of six Academy Awards) all of its many achievements are as nothing to the heart and person at its center and each aspect points in its own way to the man at the heart and succeed in effecting us as an audience much like Forrest Himself affects those around him: innocently and unassumingly taking us along on a journey that will move, amuse and even inspire. Sweet and heartwarming without losing any emotional push for it, Forrest Gump is an achievement in portraying a unique perspective on the world that draws out all of its joys and sorrows in a very poignant way. The film truly is like a box of chocolates, you might not know what you're going to get and you may not always like it but the experience is an enjoyable mix of sweet and bitter and the aftertaste is truly satisfying.


Forrest Gump, through its clear direction and talented and dedicated performers and artists, excels at portraying not only the world of Forrest Gump but the world through his eyes. Of course the flow and unity of vision in the film must be attributed to the director Robert Zemeckis and the value of the story lies with the inspiring adaptation work from Eric Roth but if I were to choose two people who defined the spirit of the film for me and truly seemed to understand and convey its themes and messages it would be Tom Hanks himself and composer Alan Sylvestri. The truth of the matter is that without Tom Hanks there would be no Forrest Gump. The words of the character and his life are all printed out in the script but it took an extra special performance to truly hit home how special Forrest really is. It is not an understatement when the poster for the film says "Tom Hanks is Forrest Gump'' because that is simply how it is. Even with his recognizable face and presence Tom Hanks becomes Forrest Gump, portraying all the simplicity and innocence, loyalty and love that Forrest has in the only way possible. That is why Tom Hanks is Forrest Gump because it could not have been anyone else. I've already said that every aspect of the film points to the man at its center and rests on his character but the character rests on Hanks and he carries the weight with wonderful skill. As Tom Hanks hides in plain sight in the film so does Alan Sylvestri's truly inspiring score. In all ways it is as simple and sweet as the main character but while it is sometimes happily so other times its simple strains can be truly heartbreaking. Each theme is so successful in creating the emotions necessary. The simple bouncing melody that represents Forrest's relationship with his mother, the tragic and somber strains of Jenny's theme and the triumphant brass whenever Forrest is running. Of all the things that give us the lens to see the film through Forrest's eyes it is the score that hides unnoticed most of the time but keeps its spirit of innocence amidst many songs of the time that appear on the soundtrack. The mixing of the pop music of the time with a simple mostly piano instrumental score is the spirit of the film captured completely on the musical spectrum. Surrounded by the culture just like Forrest yet maintaining its beautiful symplicity and emerging at the end as the element that tugged at our hearts even if we did not realize it. In all aspects the film pulls off the enormous feat of placing the audience in the heart of so many turbulent events of history yet keeps us safe in the peaceful protection of Forests honest and well meaning outlook. Forrest comes in contact with some of the worst parts of society and some of the hardest parts of living and yet he keeps going and is not swayed by all that goes on around him and thus we the audience can watch knowing that terrible things may happen but we can still rest in the quiet comfort that is simplicity. This was all said without even mentioning the cinematography, production design and ridiculously unnoticable visual effects and other strong supporting performances throughout the film. Forrest Gump is a masterclass in all aspects of filmmaking and it has a great amount of merit because of it but at the end of the day its biggest achievement is the story it tells with those elements. 

With a film that covers the highs and lows of three decades of a man's life, one can expect many deep questions to be asked and timeless lessons to be learned. One of the central messages of the film is hinted at in its very first shot of a feather blowing in the wind until finally resting at Forrest's foot as he sits at a bus stop. It is then said explicitly as Forrest mourns at Jenny's grave. He says to her  "Jenny I don't know if Momma was right or if. If it's Lieutenant Dan. I don't know if we each have a destiny, or if we're just floating around accidental like on the breeze, but I, I think maybe it's both. Maybe both is happening at the same time." The genius of the opening credits of the film is that it portrays this Idea literally while still lending to its message. The feather floats for a long time going in all directions, quite accidental like on the breeze but it finally and inevitably ends up coming across the main character. That was its destiny. And at the end of the credits one almost can think that by brushing the foot of our protagonist the feather is passing the nature of its existence on to Forrest as he recounts the story of his life, a life that he seemed to luck through. Unaware as a feather and just as poised to be blown wherever the winds of his fortune blow. Yet his life is not one happy accident after another. He still has a destiny. That which he sees and pursues. In his simple straightforward way, Forrest is pursuing his destiny much as a feather on the wind. The film's presentation of contrast between the old world of Forrest's and the new world of the sexual revolution gives ample opportunity to ponder a simple question: Does Forrest belong in the world he lives in? In other words, is this no country for Forrest? Yes the question is posed in another more explicit way in No Country For Old Men but hidden beneath the Drama of Forrest's life and the humor and heartbreak of his incongruence with the rest of the world is the question of belonging and Forrest's is an acute case of this predicament. Such is the depth of the question that it can only be pondered and it is too distant for a concrete answer on paper so I can't even begin to try and answer it. Suffice it to say that there are so many spiritual, cultural and human themes in Forrest Gump, so many joys and sorrows of the human experience that its depth can be pondered long after the Film comes to an end and before that, with so much substance as backdrop, creates an almost overwhelming cinematic experience.


At the center of every great drama there is the human person, full of flaws and doubts, misgivings and mistakes but all the while continuing to live their lives for better or worse. The central character of this drama is Forrest himself, so apart from the cares and troubles of the world and yet still doing his part to ease some suffering as he goes through his incredible journey of a life. Blissfully unaware of how truly terrible life can be, Forrest nevertheless experiences so much of the sorrows of life and comes close to so many terrible events that devastated the 60's and 70's. Forrest's relationship with those around him and to the events that surround his life is best summed up in his own words "I may not be a smart man but I know what love is" He feels compassion for such men as John F. Kennedy and John Lennon even though he can't fathom as to why they would be killed. He fights bravely in Vietnam and saves many of his fellow soldiers' lives even when he can't even begin to grasp that there is a terrible war going on around him. He cares for his girl Jenny, always looking out for her good even if he doesn't understand what tragedies have filled her life. Forrest Might be mentally unaware of all the events surrounding him but he is very aware of the people in his life and he reaches out to them in the only way he knows, with love and compassion. The two that are most affected by this are Jenny, the love of Forrest's life and Lieutenant Dan, his commanding officer in Vietnam. Both are victims of the time they live in, caught up and swept aside by the culture and the current events. Jenny grows up with an abusive father and when she gets nowhere with a folk singer career she embraces the hippie lifestyle and lives a life of destitution and despair. Lieutenant Dan was saved by Forrest in Vietnam but protested furiously, wanting to die with his men. When he loses both legs to injuries sustained in the battle he too starts a destitute life in Washington D.C. Throughout her life Jenny has come to Forrest for comfort but it is clear that because of her upbringing she does not know how to love a man like Forrest in the right way. She finally realises this and when Forrest asks her to marry him she declines and leaves the next day. Finally after three years she sends a letter to Forrest inviting him to visit her. It appears that after so much time she has finally learned why her life was so drastically different from Forrest's and is living a quiet life as a waitress and caring for her son Forrest Jr. The two finally marry and live their days happily until Jenny dies from sickness. Though Jenny lives a wild life apart from Forrest, his calm and simple presence through it all finally brings her around to recognizing the good in life. Lieutenant Dan is perplexed by Forrest's honest to goodness attitude during the war and afterwards becomes angry at Forrest for it as the two live together for a time. Lieutenant Dan states to Forrest that it was his destiny to die in Vietnam and that Forrest took it away from him. When Forrest goes to start a shrimping business Lieutenant Dan joins him, keeping a promise he made on whim that if Forrest ever bought a boat then he would be his first mate. Through Forrest's influence, Lieutenant finally realises that his life is worth living and at long last finally thanks Forrest for saving him in Vietnam. In taking a choice that may have seemed against a real "destiny" Lieutenant Dan and Forrest make their fortunes in a characteristically unexpected way and run a successful shrimping business. Through his childlike simplicity and love, Forrest's life was able to give hope and purpose to two who had none. The characters of Forrest Gump could be relatable but only to a select few. The truth of the matter is that they live human lives, lives that anyone can connect with and be moved by.

Forrest Gump is incredible. A mix of bitter and sweet, joy and sorrow, laughter and tears, tragic historical events and flights of whimsy all with its title character in the center, telling us the story of his wonderful life. Though its narrative is powerful it is nearly outshined by the prowess with which it is told. Direction, performances, music and visual effects all bringing a deeply personal story to glorious life. With a strong backbone of cultural, personal and spiritual themes, the narrative hits very deep and can resonate with all people. Of the characters only one thing can be said. The highest compliment I can give: They are human. After watching the film I thought "this is now one of my favorite films" and in the course of writing this essay I realized just how much can be said about it. What can I say except it is a true piece of art that tells a genuinely moving story.

Forrest Gump is a heartwarming, beautifully written and directed film with stellar performances by Tom Hanks and Gary Sinese. It's incredibly powerful to see the world through Gump's eyes with child-like narration, letting the director show us the underlying truth rather than saying it out loud. Watching the lead's naivety and optimism help each character heal from their trauma sends a powerful (and sometimes heartbreaking) message. The well-written story is rounded out by an amazing cast and a unique story-telling approach. It's got a long runtime, but thankfully, it uses every minute of it effectively and never feels dragging. It can occasionally feel a little dated with some of the "special" effects and directing styles, but it hardly hurts the experience at all. This film is a masterpiece as is rightly regarded as such.

"Forrest Gump" - just like its protagonist - is sweet, solemn and melancholic. Every scene is deliberate, and means something. There is not a single time in this whole movie that I found myself wanting more; it was all fantastically scripted, and performed with the upmost sincerity. I can't recommend this movie enough, it's a stone cold classic.

Forrest Gump is a 1994 film directed by Robert Zemeckis and starring Tom hanks and Robin Wright.

Forrest Gump (Tom Hanks), a slow but simple man from Alabama takes us through decades of his life, which includes various historical settings but all the while his heart is on Jenny (Robin Wright Penn), a childhood friend.

FORREST GUMP was released and quickly became a huge hit and ended up winning many Oscars. Today, for whatever reason, the film seems to be hated by many people because of the movies it beat out. I've never really understood putting too much importance on Oscars or any other award show and I really don't understand why one movie must take a beating just because of what films it beat out. ORDINARY PEOPLE takes a beating because it beat RAGING BULL. Something like DANCES WITH WOLVES takes a beating because it beat GOODFELLAS. Then there's FORREST GUMP that takes a beating because it beat out PULP FICTION or THE SHAWSHANK REDEMPTION.

As far as the film itself goes I think this is a great one. I've always liked how the film took a look at a simple person's life and a simple person who is always in very big situations yet never really understands it. There are countless bits of dialogue that are remembered by mans and they've entered the public IQ but the one dealing with knowing what love is is the one that always caught my attention as far as what this film is about. To me Gump goes through all these historic things yet it's always his love for Jenny that is the heart of the picture.

I thought the story itself was quite great and especially how we take a look at American history through the 60s, 70s and 80s. I know some people make this a political movie but I've always found that to be rather foolish. The film has a wonderful soundtrack to highlight the various eras that are shown and we also get some clever use of CGI to put Gump in the presence of people like JFK and Richard Nixon. The screenplay hits all the right notes and there's no question that technically speaking the film is impressive.

Then there are the performances that really make the movie. Hanks picked up his second Best Actor award and while I personally would have given it to Paul Newman for his performance in NOBODY'S FOOL, there's no question that Hanks is great here. He certainly nailed that "simple" man and there's not a false moment in the performance. Gary Sinise is wonderful in his role as is Mykelti Williamson in his small bit. Robin Wright Penn is the perfect opposite to Hank's character and Sally Field is good as well.

No matter what people say, FORREST GUMP is still a wonderful little gem that has a lot of great things in it.

I am not a Tom Hanks fan, but he certainly is a decent actor with a knack for getting the right projects.  'Forrest Gump' has become, and remains, almost a household name since this film's release decades ago.  It's odd too, since Forrest is a simpleton with no real agenda of his own.  His character's only point is to present a fresh lens on America circa 1955-1982.  He experiences way more of key points in history and culture than anyone possibly could, and then calls them out for what they are.  American Boomer culture is actually the main character here.  Does it work?  Maybe - as much as any unconventional narrative can.  And maybe more so if you are a Boomer.

I'm glad I finally watched this the entire way through. It was certainly long, probably even too long as some of the scenes of him being a part of history seemed unnecessary and poorly done like the Black Panther thing, but this was such a cultural phenomenon that I was certainly lacking as a well-rounded person for having avoided it for so long. I was surprised by a lot of things, most notably Tom's very narrow head. I watched this after seeing the Back to the Future series & recognized some Zemeckis characteristics in the way the narrative was framed, what with the bootstrapping protagonist. I don't think Sinise deserved an Oscar nomination for his role, though Hanks absolutely did; the decision to pile all of the negative characterization in the movie onto the girl who simply didn't love the protagonist back seemed heavy-handed and rather bizarre, as they portray her as his only real problem his entire life by showing him going through everything else without any true difficulty as they used the narration to provide his rationale for decisions to do things like rescuing his friends in the war. The narrating was obviously very good with the southern accent and the jokes, but it really was excessive as they couldn't make it through a single scene without it. Plenty of other movies use the framing of the character re-telling the story to someone else, but having so few scenes without it made the movie almost into an audiobook where you could close your eyes and never lose track of the plot. I also expected a bit more from the Oscar-nominated special effects as the historical footage had lip flap problems that relatively amateur anime dubs of the same era were conquering. Still strong viewing material, and clearly an excellent production.

Forrest Gump is one of those feel-good Hollywood movies that grows on people within age. Based on a novel, the film follows the life of Forrest Gump (Tom Hanks), a mentally-handicapped savant from Greenbow, Alabama who rides through waves of the second half of the 20th Century: meeting Elvis Presley, joining the University of Alabama's football team, meeting Presidents Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon, enlisting in Vietnam, joining the ping-pong tournament, fishing for shrimp, and even jogging across the United States. During which he starts an on-again off-again relationship with Jenny (Robin Wright) and they have a child, get married and she dies of AIDS. While not without its sappy and corny moments, the film has plenty of heart in all the right places. The best parts are Hanks's performance and his epic 30-year journey edited with him in present-day sitting on a bench talking to random passengers. It's so mesmerizing hearing his Southern accent as he tells his story and it makes you want to listen to him even more. The worst parts involve Jenny, who I believe takes advantage of Forrest and leaves him in the dust to pose for Playboy, snort cocaine, and join the Black Panther party. She doesn't even notice the fact that he traveled from one country to another just to see her again. On top of that, Jenny is probably the least interesting character in the movie as she holds accountable for its sugary syrupy moments and cliched lines. Despite my complaints, Forrest Gump is still a great all-American breakfast with just the right amount of eggs, bacon and short stacks.

An outstanding movie featuring a great central performance from Tom Hanks. It's another indication of his ability as an actor. Gary Sinise is excellent as lieutenant Dan who becomes a friend to Forrest. The film goes through important moments in American history. Forrest is the narrator who does not fully understand the significance of some of the moments. Sally Field is good as his mum providing the lessons for Forrest. We see Forrest from a young boy, a college footballer, in the army, a shrimp captain before becoming a figure for many. It's a very sweet movie interspersed with how Jenny gets drawn into many difficult life choice. Forrest longs for her but Jenny only at the end of her life understands. Watching Hanks as he talks to Jenny at her grave is very emotional as is his sadness over many in Vietnam including Bubba. The film has many funny moments as well as using songs of the era really well. Robert Zemekis has directed the film using great visual effects and CGI enabling  Forrest to appear with many key figures including presidents and John Lennon. The scenes in Vietnam with the gun fire and explosions give a sense that you are there.  The running scenes with the many spectacular scenes of America is a great love letter to its beauty. Visually stunning. Forrest never totally knows what his destiny is but ultimately many people benefit from him being in their life. The film contains many memorable quotes and the film is very watchable.

"Forrest Gump" is one of the most touching, funny and simultaneously violent films in the history of mankind. Perhaps because of such an unusual cocktail, this film has been constantly in the top three of my favorite films for years, and I can't immediately remember another such film.
"Forrest Gump" is a masterpiece of world cinema, this truth does not need to be proved, just look at the rating of the film on the Kinopoisk website with a record number of votes, just read the opinions of the audience of the film, where everyone gives the film the highest score, admiring this film or just a phrase from the film. A film that can inspire people with just one phrase is worth a lot, and when there are several of these phrases, and when the hero of the film can inspire with one of his actions…
Forrest Gump is a naive fellow, a man who lives for others, a true hero, a Saint who came down to earth to do good deeds… But no, as a person, he also faces "logical life finales", tragedies happen in the life of such a good simpleton, and that seems a big injustice. Therefore, Forrest gam is a very violent film, there is not much death on the screen, it is shown without too much pathos, but every time these moments touch to the heart.
"Forrest Gump" is the only film where, always knowing what will happen next, you want a different development of events, because such a good film should give good, and it is forced to descend from heaven, proving that any dream is limited by some earthly framework and there will never be anything unreal, everything in this life is logical and everything ends sometime.

There are no faults in the way he played Forrest. The film also has an amazing plot and message. For Forrest to not only have survived polio, but also to be most likely (even though not mentioned in the film) on the autism spectrum or to have autism, shows how anyone can do anything. The heartfelt story also had amazing little tie-ins to the time period, like how Forrest inspired Elvis's dancing, or how Forrest called in The Watergate Scandal. I actually laughed at the later moment, finding it very amusing. Also including moments and groups, such as the Vietnam War, The Black Panther Party, The War Hawks and Peace Dove, and the multiple assassinations/assassination attempts were so important to add as they helped define the period, were seamlessly added into the plot. Also the moments of Forrest, not realizing the severity of the situation he is in, but just wanting help someone, are very heart warming and show how we must all treat each other with respect. For example: When he picks up the African-American student's notebook and hands it to here, not caring about what could happen, or knowing about the situation that was really going on. Or when he goes back and saves the men, even when he is looking for Bubba and could die in the line of fire, especially Lieutenant Dan. 
There are only two moments I find fault with (even those are minor and have reasoning behind them). One: When Jenny leaves Forrest the last time, it was confusing onto why she left him again?. But it is in her character to run away and not confront her problems, until she does at the very end asking Forrest Gump to marry her, giving her an arc. and Two: How his boat, Jenny, made it full circle without a driver and crashed into the dock? It makes no sense, even if you factor in current and wind. But the moment is funny, especially how Hanks causally delivers the lines that follow, so it is fine.
Anyone who is breathing has to see this before they die, or they will regret.

Some of its moments haven't aged well and others feel cheesy. But overall it's a charming and emotive movie with a message about fate, discrimination and misjudgment. It story may be too emotional, but it's redeemed by its groundbreaking visual effects and Tom Hank's charismatic and complex lead performance.

Forrest Gump (1994) is a movie that follows a man, Forrest Gump, with a low IQ who keeps accidentally finding himself in many important and historical moments. This movie is full of intertextuality with real life, such as the Vietnam War, The Black Panther Party, and the Ping Pong diplomacy. I believe that the intertextualities in this movie help the director present the movie's political stance. A movie's political stance is the thoughts that the movie tries to instill in people's minds to either teach them something or make them act a certain way. In order for a movie to have a political stance, it needs to have an ideological position – a system of beliefs. The politics and ideology of Forrest Gump are ones that advocate for simplicity and patience. Through the form and content – where the form is the way the movie is shot and content is the dialogue – one can notice that the movie is saying that leading a simple life, being an honest person, and not complicating things like Forrest, can lead you to accomplishing great things. 
	The movie's political stance is not one that can be noticed easily since it relies on macro narratives, where the audience need to look at the bigger picture and link all the events of the movie together to understand what idea the movie trying to spread. It feels like the movie itself was conscious of its themes of simplicity, but Forrest was not.  Forrest was often unaware of the importance of the events happening around him such as the Hippie movement or being dragged into the Black Panther Party, however, everyone else around him was. Jenny, Forrest's love interest and his first ever friend, was aware that the successes he reached to, such as being awarded the Medal of Honor and being really rich due to his shrimp business, was due to the fact that he was an honest man who always did the right thing. Forrest's patience for Jenny to love him back ended up in them starting a family.
	Just like any other movie, Forrest Gump relies on elements such as irony, foreshadowing, and architecture to present its plot and political stance. I found it ironic how when Forrest started telling his story to people, he explained the origins of his name to a black woman. This is ironic because he was named after his ancestor, the founder of the The Klu Klux Klan, a hate group that targeted African Americans and supported slavery. The irony of this scene, however, sets the floor for the political stance to start forming, since Forrest thinks in the simplest way to the point where he did not realize that it is probably not a good idea to tell an African American woman that he was related to the founder of the KKK. 
	Forrest Gump relies heavily on foreshadowing. It was foreshadowed that Forrest and Jenny would eventually end up together from the beginning of the movie when Jenny and Forrest were sitting together on a tree branch and then Jenny holds his hand and tells him to stay with her a little longer. When Jenny and Forrest went to different universities, Forrest would visit her in her university. One time, Forrest saw her in a car with another man and they were engaged in a sexual interaction however it seemed to hurt Jenny. Forrest stepped in and pulled the man away from her even though he could have ended up in a fight with the man. This scene foreshadowed two important things, first, Jenny would end up in a lot of abusive relationships, and second, Forrest will always be loyal and protective of her no matter how much it would hurt him. Moreover, the movie also relies on referencing itself in order to foreshadow upcoming events. This can be seen in the scene when Forrest rides the bus on his way to the army and no one would let him sit next to them except for Bubba. The movie is refencing itself because a similar scene happened in the beginning of the movie when Forrest rode the bus on his way to school and only Jenny would let him sit next to her. This self-referencing foreshadowed that Forrest and Bubba were to be best friends and that Forrest would remain loyal to him.
	Moreover, the movie uses its architecture to foreshadow and build up its political stance. The architecture of a movie consists of the buildings and the lighting of the movie – in other words, it is the design of the movie's environment. Forrest and his mother live in a big house in the rural Alabama. Rural areas are characterized by simplicity and honesty. Forrest living in a simple environment foreshadows that Forrest himself will grow up to be a simple man. Since children are the product of their environment, and the accomplishments of one are a product of who they are, then the environment you grew up in causes your accomplishments. Forrest living in a rural area helps the movie's political stance because all of Forrest's accomplishments are due to simplicity.
	Forrest Gump is a brilliant movie that uses many aspects of films and links them together in a unique way to present its political stance. The political stance of Forrest Gump is leading a simple life and having patience can lead you to accomplishing great things. The movie presents its politics through the use of irony, foreshadowing and architecture. I really enjoyed this movie and I would recommend others to watch it.

"Forrest Gump" is just an epic movie that touches people throughout all ages and generations. The simplicity of this film is the main reason to love it. This is a movie of a heart-breaker of oddball wit and startling grace. There's talk of another Oscar for Tom Hanks.In a college dorm with Jenny, who lets him touch her breast, the virginal Forrest ejaculates instantly, losing her interest and his self-respect. In the Army, Forrest saves his captain (Gary Sinise), whose legs are later amputated, and the captain resents him. Forrest is everything we admire in the American character - honest, brave, loyal - and the film's fierce irony is that nobody can stay around him for long. Zemeckis doesn't fall into the trap of using Forrest as an ad for arrested development. He knows the limits of a holy fool who can't understand the hypocrisy of postwar America that this picaresque epic so powerfully reveals. The peace-love pretensions of the '60s are skewered as neatly as the greed decades that follow. But there is something of Forrest that Zemeckis would like to see rub off on us: his capacity for hope. It's an ambitious goal in this age of rampant cynicism. Godspeed.

"Forrest Gump" is a movie I enjoy watching.  The lines in this movie are memorable and can sometimes be funny. There's Forrest Gump who's played by Tom Hanks with an IQ right below average. But his mom let's Forrest know that there's nothing that can hold him back. He's is made fun of in school and no one will let him sit next to them on the bus. He has to wear leg braces, has a crooked back, and does not have too many friends. One girl, Jenny tells him he can sit with heron the bus. Jenny ends up being Forrest's best friend and crush. Unfortunately, for Jenny we find out her and her sisters are being sexually abused by their father. Jenny ends up with a lifetime of drug and alcohol abuse that unfortunately costs her life. One day, Forrest and Jenny are walking to school and there are some mean kids calling Forrest stupid and throwing rocks at him. Jenny yells to Forrest "Run Forrest, Run!"and  he breaks the braces off of his legs and runs incredibly fast. Throughout the movie Forrest meets many celebrities, including: Elvis Presley, President Kennedy, President Johnson, President Nixon, and John Lennon. Although, the best people he meets along the way are Bubba and Lieutenant Dan , his Vietnam war friends, Bubba wants to own a great shrimp boat one day.  Bubba is similar to Forrest, he also has a learning disability.  Unfortunately in the Vietnam War, Bubba dies, and Lieutenant Dan loses his leg in a huge attack. Forrest was saving soldiers including Lieutenant Dan from running in and out of the battlefield. For his bravery, Forrest ends up receiving a  medal of honor. Down the line, Forrest ends up saving Lieutenant Dan again. He finds him in New York, a depressed alcoholic. From there Forrest and Lieutenant Dan go on to pursue Bubba's dream and establish the Bubba Gump shrimp boat in honor of Bubba. The shrimp boat ends up being a huge success for Forrest and Lieutenant Dan. It ends up making them a whole lot of money. Lieutenant Dan's depression goes away and he gets himself a fresh new pair of prosthetic legs. Towards the end of the movie, Jenny comes back into Forrest's life. She realizes she is not well and is dying and comes to tell Forrest that they had a kid together. Forrest takes care of Jenny up until her last day. From then on out, it's just Forrest and his son Forrest Jr. At the very end of the movie, Forrest forgets about everything and just runs, very very far. Until he gets aged features on his face and a huge beard.  In my opinion, the movie Forrest Gump is a must watch and has a very empowering theme to it. From the famous lines in the movie to the humorous and emotionally powerful scenes, it's an overall iconic and legendary film. The reason I liked this movie the most is the meaning of the movie, at least what I got out of watching it, is to never give up!

On July 6, 1994, Paramount unveiled Robert Zemeckis' Forrest Gump in theaters. The Tom Hanks satire would go on to win six Oscars at the 67th Academy Awards, including best picture. The Hollywood Reporter's original review is below:

Forrest Gump is not stupid. Although his IQ is 75, he sees the world far clearer than most. Through his decent, childlike eyes, we too see things in a less confused and muddled way. In this cheerfully straight-arrow moral tale, Tom Hanks stars as the "wise fool" Forrest Gump and delivers yet another Oscar-level performance. Paramount will win sensational box office with this Robert Zemeckis-directed film. 

Raised in the '50s in rural Alabama by a single mother (Sally Field), Forrest, being "different," must fend for himself, struggling against not only perceived expectations but boyhood bullies. He unwittingly finds that he's blessed with a talent — he can run like the wind, which wins him a football scholarship to play for Bear Bryant at the University of Alabama. And there's no stopping him after that.

An uplifting saga about one young boy's earnest and good-natured attempts to overcome his disabilities, Forrest Gump is also a cheeky social satire of the past 40 years of U.S. social-political history. Eric Roth's screenplay, adapted from Winston Groom's novel, nimbly intertwines Forrest's life with the seminal social events and players of the past several decades. Unassuming Forrest, with his golly-gee enthusiasm and inbred decency, encounters the likes of Elvis, George Wallace, presidents Kennedy through Nixon, Dick Cavett, John Lennon and Abbie Hoffman as he graduates from 'Bama, fights in Vietnam, competes in international ping-pong, founds a shrimping company, engages in philanthropy and jogs cross-country. 

Contrasting Forrest's unassuming innocence with the upheavals and rancor of the times, the film is a wisely goofy commentary on the stupidity of smartness. 

While Forrest's foray's into the dens of the big and powerful are cheekily amusing, the film ambles along over a deeper, darker layer: Forrest's love for his childhood girlfriend, Jenny (Robin Wright). An abused child, Jenny's life path is a desperate wander to find solid ground. She falls prey to every social movement and fad of the times; unlike Forrest, whose unwavering strength and sense of right and wrong protect him from being caught up in social slides, Jenny's genuflections reflect her lack of firm values and inner confidence. 

To some extent, one could argue that Jenny symbolizes most of us. If any criticism might be leveled at the film, it is that its most heart-wrenching moments are too adeptly skirted, but, then again, that's in keeping with Forrest's strength. Highest praise to Zemeckis, who has reached a higher maturity plane with his gracefully, technically eloquent direction. 

Carrying his torso in an erect, straight-arched manner, Hanks' body language is all-telling. With each strange or perplexing situation, Hanks erupts with the smallest twitch or turn, signaling Forrest's deep-seated disapproval or, in special other cases, his gleeful, thankful wonderment. Mykelti Williamson, as Forrest's simple-minded G.I. buddy, is also outstanding, while Gary Sinise is sympathetic as Forrest's bitter platoon leader, legless after the Vietnam War.

Robert Zemeckis' Forrest Gump (1994) is a sweet romance drama with a distinctive comedic style. Tom Hanks' narration is fun and strictly from his mentally challenged character Forrest Gump's childlike perspective. This keeps Forrest Gump innocent as a film, but thoughtful for the audience who know the historical events are real and have meaning.

My major gripe with Forrest Gump is its ridiculous bloated run-time. It could easily have lost a whole half hour to ease the audience into this story. It's takes awhile before much of anything interesting happens and focuses too much on silly moments in Gump's life.

I do think there is a fair criticism to be made about Hanks' performance as just using a simple minded man as a means to awards praise. This movie does little to make you understand Gump's perspective until he says he may be stupid, but he understands love to Jenny.

I like Tom Hanks' warm and likable performance, but Forrest Gump is stolen by the charismatic and tragic portrayal of a Vietnam veteran Lieutenant Dan by Gary Sinise. He captures the humor and depression of his situation that makes the movie feel so real, even though it's all a fantasy.

You can say that Robin Wright is great as Jenny, but her character is detestable, as she uses Gump when she needs him, but does not offer any kindness in return. Jenny is a complex figure in cinematic history. She is important to Gump as she is his friend, but you wonder why she never feels as real as Hanks' quaint man. Sally Field is at least supportive and kindly as his odd mother.

Both Forrest and Jenny feel more like representations of their era instead of complete characters. Forrest is the all American athlete and Vietnam veteran that turns into a businessman and family figure. While Jenny is the abused girl that turns into a victimized woman, who engages in drug addiction and the hippy lifestyle until her world is turned upside down and she has no options left but Forrest. I question the moral of Forrest Gump as it never feels clear if they are saying there is a God or not like Jenny says, or if everything is up to destiny as Dan says. I think that Forrest's whole life is all random chance encounters and dumb luck, so was there really a message at all?

Anyways, Zemeckis' direction is stellar and focused. Forrest Gump is easily one of his greatest films. Alan Silvestri's score is dreamy and romantic with a healthy amount of sentimental nostalgia for the past. The soundtrack to Forrest Gump is killer and very representative of its generations throughout the film.

Overall, Forrest Gump is an undeniable classic movie in Americana. I think it has some flaws, but it is always entertaining.

I couldn't tell you how many times I have seen this film and yet I have never been disappointed or bored by it. It's lovely and impressive all at once the way it weaves together a decade spanning story featuring nearly every major historical figure and event of those eras and a sweet personal story of a man's love for a troubled woman. Tom Hanks' performance in the lead role is genius and great actors like Sally Field and Gary Sinise make their mark in small but memorable roles. The term feel-good is used to describe a lot of movies that possibly don't deserve it but this is a fantastical but genuinely heartwarming tale that mixes dark humor and slapstick to create an unforgettable film.

Forrest Gump, Tom Hanks, is a man who mentally isn't entirely there but his love of life and willingness to try anything allow him to be successful and as he encounters the Vietnam War, the Olympics and the run across the United States he succeeds. The one goal that he struggles to achieve however is obtaining the affection of the love of his life, Jenny, Robin Wright, who has been sexually abused by her Father and faces drug addiction, suicidal thoughts and prostitution as she grows older. Throughout the film we see their diverging paths and when they are finally reunited it is bittersweet but the final scene of Gump dropping his son of at the bus stop is a tear-jerking moment.

The lead character is an oddity because he doesn't really face any obstacles in achieving great professional success, we are aware that some of those around him snigger at him cruelly but he is unaware of this and is able to become a war hero and shrimp millionaire with very little effort. Even the difficulties he faces in getting Jenny to love him are largely her battling her own demons while he waits for her to come around but this all magically works and he is one of the most compelling heroes ever written. The iconic lines in the film "Life is like a box of chocolates, you never know what you're gonna get" and "Run, Forrest, run" are entertaining. But the screenplay also allows for some very dark moments such as when it is implied that Jenny and her sisters have been sexually abused and that Forrest's Mother will have to provide sexual favors to the school administrator for him to continue attending the school. 

Jenny is interesting in that we understand her tragic backstory and we see her trying to strive to achieve something greater, she joins several protest movements, and because of that her failures hurt. When we realize that she is a prostitute attempting to play music instead of stripping it is devastating and her resistances to the interventions of Forrest are frustrating from an audience perspective but also understandable as she wants to be able to save herself instead of relying on a man. We see her intermittently, when compared to Forrest, but her influence over him is always felt as his desire to be with her triumphs over all other goals in his life and the tenderness he feels for her is felt by the audience as we see their son, a product of their love, with the same joy that they do.

The direction of this film was surely difficult as a lot needs to be stuffed into the film without it feeling overwhelming and the story needs to be whimsy and sentimental but at times dark without feeling tonally all over the place. Zemeckis directs the film so that is always compelling, funny, touching, sweet and most importantly, human, the tone of the film never feels like it wavers too dramatically even though it does often shift and Zemeckis' ability to capture all of those emotions is perfectly suited to a very emotional film. Hanks also walks a tightrope as a character who could very easily be offensive to those who are  mentally disabled, to some his portrayal is, but I think he pulls of Forrest's rose-colored lens attitude extremely well and handles both the comedic and dramatic elements that the performance requires with care. These two talented professionals bring to life this difficult to execute story.

Considering this film within the context of 1994 I still genuinely believe that this was the best mainstream film to come out of that year, yes there is a lot of love for The Shawshank Redemption (1994) and Four Weddings and a Funeral (1994) but this has to walk a harder balancing act and it pulls it off extremely well. In terms of more independent films to come out that year I would say Three Colors: White was a great black comedy but it was unlikely that something so out there was going to get a Best Picture nomination without a bully like Harvey Weinstein pushing it. This is a brilliant film that everyone should see and it's one of those Best Picture wins that has aged well.

The biggest picture of 1994 and one I only got round to watching last night in 2019, some 25 years later. Why had I left it so long? Several reasons which I will list in no particular order:
1) Tom Hanks. I must admit to not been particularly endeared to the actor although I have seen several good films in his filmography.
2) The running time of well over 140 minutes has always put me off.
3) Clips showing Hanks as the title character, Forrest Gump muttering phrases such as 'Life is like a box of chocolates, you never know quite what your gonna get..'

Anyway actually watching it took me through the interesting life of a fictional character Gump, a man with low I.Q. but who has lived closely through several notable points in U.S. history up to 1994.
1. Elvis Presley's dancing routine which a childhood Gump inadvertently introduces to the King whilst limping in leg braces.
2. Serving in the bloody battlefields of the Vietnam War. Single handedly rescuing half his platoon and introducing fascinating characters including his wounded Platoon Lieutenant Dan Taylor (Gary Sinise).
3. Meeting several U.S. Presidents including JFK as a member of his college football team, and Richard Nixon when being awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor.
In the process witnessing the Watergate break in whilst staying at the Watergate Hotel at the recommendation of Nixon!
4. His 'love' interest throughout the film Jenny Curran contracting an incurable virus in the early 1980s after a lifestyle of drug addiction? AIDS?
5. A segment including a TV interview with the late John Lennon.
It was funny seeing Gump interwoven into old footage of famous people from the past 40 years or so.
Director Robert Zemekis, the man who brought Back To The Future to cinema audiences was behind this film and crowd pleasing elements of that film can be seen in Forrest Gump.
Tom Hanks delivers a great performance showing and narrating Forrest Gump's life on a bus stop bench to fascinated passers by.
The running time actually goes quite fast.
The supporting cast including Sinise deliver excellent performances and add to Gump's fascinating lifestory.

Forrest Gump is simply a perfect movie. The way I define my favorite movies is actually the way my mom defines her favorite movies. She defines it as a movie that you can rewatch several times and never get tired of it. A movie where you care about the main character. A movie that makes you feel whatever itâ(TM)s supposed to make you feel. And finally, a movie that you feel a connection with. It took me awhile to realize it, but the more I thought about it, Forrest Gump actually fit all those qualifications and more. I also love to do impressions and Forrest Gump is one of my favorite impressions to do. Its got an incredible soundtrack, its endlessly quotable, the special effects are unbelievable, you learn a lot about American history (which makes it a perfect classroom movie), every actor gives a great performance, it makes you laugh, it makes you cry, and it even makes you think. Thereâ(TM)s also a religious aspect that I personally appreciate. Honestly, how can anyone not love this movie? Well it has received some backlash, but I still donâ(TM)t get why. Most people probably donâ(TM)t even know that itâ(TM)s based on a book. A book thatâ(TM)s drastically different and doesnâ(TM)t compare to the movie at all. People point out that it has a bad moral, that the romance is one sided, that itâ(TM)s too feel good. First off, Forrest is not meant to be a character who goes through a lot of character development. He does what people say, but he helps people by doing it. Heâ(TM)s caring, protective, and always does the right thing despite his limited intelligence. Second off, the romance is not too one sided. Jenny comes from a difficult upbringing and its very likely sheâ(TM)d make bad decisions. Forrest was always there for her even when she wanted to push him away. And in the end, they were better together then apart. Third off, âtoo feel good.â? What does that even mean? I donâ(TM)t know about you, but Iâ(TM)ll take feel good over relentlessly depressing anyday. Forrest Gump even managed to win Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor Tom Hanks, Best Adapted Screenplay, Best Visual Effects, and Best Editing at the Academy Awards among some pretty stiff competition. While some people might not understand it, Forrest Gump is my favorite movie. It never fails to make me laugh, give me hope, and the ending makes me cry every time I see it (every time). One of Robert Zemeckisâ(TM) absolute best. âAnd thatâ(TM)s all I have to say about that.â?
